texts.shortText: Found exclusively growing as an epiphyte on kelps of the genus Ecklonia. Several erect, flattened main axes emerge from a base which penetrates the tissues of the host.  Main axes are long and flattened and bear irregular lateral branches of various lengths. These in turn are lined by a frill of tiny branchlets (which may even have even more smaller branchlets along their margins!). Colour reddish-brown.
Main blades up to about 300 mm tall, and typically about 2-3 mm wide.

Global: Chile and Southern African.

Local/Regional: Namibia to de Hoop, on Ecklonia maxima, but also extends to Eastern Cape on E. radiata.
A very common epiphyte of Sea bamboo Ecklonia maxima, often forming dense growths on older fronds.

Reproductive structures found in marginal branches. There is a complex life cycle involving both a sporophyte (spore producing) generation and similar-looking separate male and female gametophyte (gamete producing) generations.

Both growth form and habitat distinctive, but several other epiphytic frilly red algae also occur on kelps, including Red ribbons Gelidium vittatum and Hypnea ecklonii. The much smaller C. minima occurs on Split-fan kelp Laminaria pallida.

Anderson, RJ, Rothman, MD, Share, A, et al. (2006). Harvesting of the Kelp Ecklonia maxima in South Africa affects Its three obligate, red algal epiphytes. Journal of Applied Phycology, 18, 343–349.
